channel.description: Recent content in philosophy on rs.io

item.title: A 60-Second Exercise That Boosts Goal Achievement By 20%
item.description: The hero of our tale, Jason Padgett. (Content note: this is an example of what I send out to email subscribers.

item.title: Spinach, unhealthy? Reflections on one month vegan
item.description: Rewind. It’s August of last year. I’ve just published a post on the reasoning behind certain “strange” beliefs.

item.title: Prolonged Eye Contact and Attraction: What The Science Tells Us
The Unreasonable Effectiveness of Checklists
item.description: Dr. Peter Provonost had a problem. People were dying and — to borrow a line from Fight Club — not in the Sylvia Plath, Tibetan Buddhist, we’re-all-dying-so-get-used-to-it sense of the word.

item.title: The Creative Process Demystified
item.description: Jack Kerouac is a liar. Okay, let me rewind. I don’t know how much experience you’ve had with creative writing types — pale, imaginative creatures — but let me tell you how they talk about Jack Kerouac.

item.title: Creativity, Literature, and Compression
item.description: But first, a joke: I was at a bar last weekend, chatting with this woman.

item.title: What affects your personal identity? You’re a sponge.
item.description: That thing is the most badass of all sea slugs, the nudibranch.

item.title: The Secretary Problem Explained: Dating Mathematically
item.description: I was, to put it mildly, something of a mess after my last relationship imploded.

item.title: Effective Study Skills for College Students: “Why?” Questions
item.description: Consider two sentences: The llama was made out of watermelon flavored cactus.

item.title: Love Is Not A Choice And Other Tools For Thinking
item.description: I’m not much of a romantic. If I wanted to hack romance I’d start with going through all the literature on the mate preferences of chimpanzees, bonobos, and great apes generally.

item.title: Love Is Not A Choice And Other Tools For Thinking
item.description: I’m not much of a romantic. If I wanted to hack romance I’d start with going through all the literature on the mate preferences of chimpanzees, bonobos, and great apes generally.

item.title: What Makes Something Interesting?
item.description: Francis Galton, cousin of Charles Darwin and maybe best known for his work on intelligence, was a bit obsessed with the idea that people have certain innate traits.

item.title: The Science of Habit
item.description: The truth is that everyone is bored, and devotes himself to cultivating habits.

item.title: Why Replication Is Important
item.description: Every bit of evidence one can acquire, in any area, leads one that much closer to what is true.

item.title: Expert Memory: What Can Memory Experts Teach Us?
item.description: That which we persist in doing becomes easier, not that the task itself has become easier, but that our ability to perform it has improved.

item.title: Future Generations Are Your Legacy, All Of Them
item.description: I have heard tell of a time in a man’s life where he begins to worry less about his own dreams and invests more in living through his children.

item.title: When Is It OK To Break The Rules?
item.description: I propose a new way of thinking about rules. Not as something that distinguishes between what one is allowed and not allowed to do, but rather as a penalty that certain actions carry.

item.title: Thoughts On The Police Body Cameras Privacy Debate
item.description: There’s a link on Reddit to the sort of story that the internet can’t get enough of: police abuse.

item.title: What Is Wisdom?
item.description: There’s an art to knowing when; Never try to guess.

item.title: What Is Wisdom?
item.description: There’s an art to knowing when; Never try to guess.
